Wrong. The economy does not equal the market. Cisco, is a tech leader in networking solutions for enterprises, theyve beat earnings repeatedly and is always in the conversation when it comes to networking, yet they still havent reached their all time highs in 20 years. It took Amazon 10 years to reach theirs when they plummeted. Along with the NASDAQ. 

The market cap of I think the top 3 companies in the sp500 are all tech and above 1-2 trillion and the top 10 are approaching near half a trillion.

What happens when there is no more new money in large caps because the market is noticing small and mid caps are promising more returns. Just because its a good company or a thriving sector, it doesn't mean its fairly valued and represents the economy, it could end up moving sideways for years till small/mid or even other sectors catch up. You could be stagnate with overpriced tech stocks till the market decodes the rotation finishes

author: Led_-zeppelin
body:
>You can overpay for growth  
>  
> regardless of how good the company is, and that's exactly what Cathie is doing.

I think the issue here is to double check what the thesis on this companies where at the time to see what made you overpay for growth or not. Cathy can be overpaying for growth (and I think she is in most of her picks) but in some  she must just be right and I think she knows that she doesn't need to be right in 100% of them just on a few to be wildly successful, Just like what happen with Tesla, She had a bull target price of $7000 pre split ($1400 slit adjusted) and everyone thought her crazy and now you see her base case being the most common price targets for this year and her 2017's bull case being likely more and more (and I think it was a price target for 2024 so she still has time for Tesla to reach that valuation).

Also regarding Cisco, I don't particularly remember the "bull case" for Cisco that "validated" its price during the Dot Com bubble,  but I would argue if simplified  it would look like this "everyone will be using the internet in the future so the company that has the technology that will allow everyone to be connected to the internet will be a goldmine". Not a bad idea or logic other than the technology got commoditized and 20 years later everyone has a router in their house like people assumed in 1999/2000 but nobody cares what brand it is and the devices that actually keep us connected to the internet in the most convenient way (smartphones) is actually designed by the most valuable company in the world and its competitor doesn't even make the hardware at all (Google with Android).

What people didn't saw in the 2000's with their "bull case" for Cisco (The creation of the smartphone and how it changed internet access from home to on the go was the biggest culprit here)  is the reason why Cisco hasn't recovered in share price because people bought into growth that never materialized . I agree you can overpay for growth but you will only be certain of it after the fact when your thesis is validated or completely changes for better or worse.  You can overpay for growth and you can also miss opportunities of decades or even lifetimes, this is why you have to double check your thesis if you are investing into this type of companies that will have massive growth in the future to see if the growth is actually there or not.

author: play_it_safe
body:
First, what's interesting is that I come from a similar background and had the same thinking for a long time. But the more I thought about it, the more I reconsidered. 

What's interesting is that the bust cycle for tech already happened. That was Cisco. Every industry has done this. Renewables did a decade ago. Now they're fairly mature revenue generating companies (FSLR off top of my head). 

I think with big tech, it's had those growing pains already. MSFT AAPL especially came back from the dead after that that bust. These are no Cisco. That died basically. Or Standard Oil. Or GM (which I think is reinventing itself nicely, but that's another story). Or INTC (which is dying...). AAPL MSFT AMZN especially have huge competitive advantages across industries, own Washington and continue to curb any attempt at serious regulation, and continue to create and recreate entirely new industries. Especially with huge profit margins, sticky revenue streams, and TAM that continue to multiply as they suck in every other industry in existence (I'm not kidding:AMZN still owns the cloud, and that's not an easy yoke to throw off for clients. MSFT has bought out gaming, AAPL into cars, which may or may not be good idea, and services like banking). They are in part infrastructure companies, too. They can't fail. Or the increasingly digitized economy fails. One Google outage cost the world billions. For all of that, I'm happy to pay the multiples you put out. They're peanuts. AAPL also has enough cash on hand and the acumen to spend it wisely that the Swiss Central Bank bought millions worth during covid crash (it was huge). You're investing in with something that has the power and wealth of a freaking nation state. Dying? No problem. FB bought out Instagram. 

Moats upon moats, and network effects. These are all something former giants didn't have, and not something that could be said of any former businesses that went bust. No one trick ponies here. 

NFLX isn't worthwhile in my opinion. Nor is TSLA. The ones I named are. For all the reasons I gave.

If you're concerned about valuations, you need to consider interest rates. Both Schiller and Buffett have talked about how given persistent low interest rates in the developed world, the equity premium right now is, well, not a premium. They're the only way to generate returns. And may well remain so.

Here's a guy that's been consistently correct for the past two years on valuations and overall market behavior. He's spot on about the numbers. Very good recent article by him: https://www.fidelity.com/learning-center/trading-investing/is-the-market-at-a-top

I don't disagree with you. But to compare something like AAPL to Cisco or to Standard Oil is to completely misunderstand the nature of their businesses and their staying power and what they've become. And that's why Buffett continues to hold an ungodly amount. Did he buy the former giants? I'm sure you respect him, right? 😉

author: M_Scaevola
body:
A moat in consumer products is easy enough to spot. Progressive in car insurance (right now at least, maybe Geico makes a comeback). Apple in computers. Walmart. Amazon. Mars Candy. It’s all qualitative in nature though, so I don’t know how useful a service for that would be.

Getting outside of consumer facing entities, you tend to need some familiarity with the industry (this is why lynch stresses local knowledge). Cisco for networking technologies. Microsoft and Oracle both dominate database markets, even with cloud in roads.

Conglomerates or even large business with multiple product lines may have moats in some areas, but not in others. Activision has a moat with candy crush, but they gave up their market share with World of Warcraft through sheer stupidity. Nintendo partially owns the Pokémon Company. But both companies also have a lot of other baggage that may hurt the company.

author: MightyManorMan
body:
TEC looks like maybe half my portfolio... it's based on [https://www.solactive.com/Indices/?index=DE000SLA6X91](https://www.solactive.com/Indices/?index=DE000SLA6X91)

The problem with indexes like this is that they create a basket of the winners and losers. For example, in the doghouse of stocks I wouldn't buy from the index, Cisco (they are basically asleep at the wheel, for about 8 years, no innovation, no growth), Intel (single digit growth), Visa (Square is growing quickly, MasterCard is growing better than Visa). Just to give a few examples.

Also, because these are indexes, they tend to look at more established companies and miss the exponential growth stage.

author: homeless_alchemist
body:
I don't understand doximity's valuation at all. I think it's grossly overvalued. They basically create tools and a networking platform for physicians. They then monetize their physician network via allowing pharma and hospital systems to market to them. They're upside is capped by how niche their focus is. Though, I guess they could try to branch into physician adjacent fields, if they start to plateau. 

I have used doximity's patient dialer during covid and it was really effective, but now that covid isn't as bad and my hospital transitioned to Cisco Jabber, I have little reason to use it now.

author: swingkid72
body:
Please explain what “based on the timeline means”. By my calculation $100k invested in AAPL on 9/1/1996 (roughly 25 years ago) would be worth about $68.8 million. Still an enormous gain that more than proves the point you’re trying to make, but a long way from $73.8 billion. 

Also, the point holds for those who had the foresight and/or luck to invest in AAPL or AMZN then, but not for any number of tech companies that that went under during the dot com crash, or even some of those that have survived to this day, like Cisco, that still has yet to reach the ATH it made in 1997.  

So the idea that it doesn’t matter what price you buy a company at, if you just hold long enough, you will eventually profit, is false.

author: AnalbolicHazelnut
body:
I really like the VGT pick. Let's have a look at the top 10 holdings of the fund that account for 57.4%.
 
1 Apple 19.58%

2 Microsoft 16.53%

3 Nvidia 4.22%

4 Visa 3.16%

5 Mastercard 2.76%

6 Paypal 2.76%

7 Adobe 2.39%

8 Intel 1.94%

9 Salesforce 1.91%

10 Cisco 1.90%

There is some hardware in there but most of the revenue on that list comes from software by subscription and that is with out a doubt the best business model of all time. It's almost cheating. Those are almost comming a part of the infastructure, with the margins that it brings when the company has matured. Those are all great companies to own.

With that beeing said, you are paying a premium for those companies right now. Now, ofcourse that is the case with most of the top holdings in any ETF, but big and mega cap tech are in my opinion due for a _mild_ correction that won't stay long. Or at the very least,  a slower climb moving forwards. 

If this is a decent amount that you are going to be investing, I recommend that you start of with at least half in a lump sum and then periodecly re-invest the next 24 months. Or 12. Or at least 6. I think you should make the innitial more VTI heavy and aventually end it in the 70-30. 

Or don't. This might be overthinking it wich is not really in tune with your tech heavy bogglehead approuch. I would add in a little VOO but I still like your picks. In the end, it properbly doesn't matter.

author: BigBrianBrand
body:
I had a feeling Cisco and the dot com crash was going to get brought up. It's a popular forced bear narrative on this sub for any tech company. You could have said this same thing during the August 2015 and December 2018 crashes, because the market is somehow always in a bubble.

And honestly, you are showing your lack of knowledge trying to compare an IT company in a less established industry at the time that had dealt with interest rates at 5.5%, versus a digital advertising company that has 91% global market share in a near-zero interest rate environment.

Google brings in $80B in Operating Income on a $1.8T Market Cap.

'00 Cisco's financials are not even remotely comparable. They had only $20B in revenue on a $550B market cap.

As for cyclicality, there are always market corrections every so often. Let me know when marketing has a 10-year decline.

Please please please actually study up on the dot com crash and Microsoft/Cisco/Dell/Intel before trying to start comparing them to FAAMG on a stock forum.

author: flatirony
body:
Thanks for the well written post.   I disagree with it but I’m happy to have the discussion.  

First of all I should clarify that I am an infrastructure engineer for an internet company.  Not one of the biggest ones, but one you’ve heard of.   So
one way that I follow the advice in your username is not to put all of my eggs in one basket by also investing heavily in tech.

On valuations, that was my ballpark estimate for big Tech.  I looked the numbers up just now and feel really good about them.   Here are the forward/trailing P/E’s for these companies:

AMZN   59/58
AAPL    26/29
GOOG  30/31
MSFT   32/36
FB         28/26
NFLX    50/54

This averages to 38, without even including smaller and less mature growth tech.  Much less Tesla.

And I personally believe that those P/E’s are based on optimistically flawed macro assumptions, for reasons OP touched on.  

I understand that P/E isn’t the only measure of value and can even be a dangerous one (clearly $ZIM’s 2021 P/E of under 2 is not sustainable).

But it pretty much boils down to what you’re paying for a combination of sustainable earnings and growth potential.

I know these are considered the best and most revolutionary businesses ever.  But I also know that the same thing has been said about most of the biggest businesses in history.  It was definitely said of Cisco in 1999, but also of IBM and GE and GM and Standard Oil and the Pennsylvania Railroad.  I majored in the history of technology, I’ve always been interested in this phenomenon.

This week I have been reading David McCullough’s history of the Panama Canal.   

The French Suez and Panama Canal companies were each by far the biggest IPO’s in history. The same guy, Ferdinand de Lesseps, was the CEO both times.  The Suez was a legendary success, the Panama an abject failure.  A total loss for shareholders, who were still much better off than the perhaps 20,000 employees who died of malaria and yellow fever. 

The French capital raises for the Panama Canal project in the 1880’s remind me a great deal of recent going’s on

We especially hear how it’s different this time late in each business cycle.  And we are very late in this cycle.  I believe we are in the 12th year of it, from the stock market POV, because 2020 only produced a tiny blip and it was off to the races again.

$SPX has returned over 18% CAGR since the 2009 bottom.  The highest ever *rolling* 10 year nominal return is about 20%, and that was in a little higher inflation regime than we had in the 2010’s, along with much higher interest rates.  Thus I would posit that overall in the last 12 years we have seen the highest 10-year equity risk premium in history.  And roughly tied for the highest ever real returns.

And that’s using $SPX.  The Nasdaq 100 has been considerably better.  Meanwhile small caps are much more overvalued than big tech, with a higher P/E ratio.  A fair number of straight up zombies litter $IWM.

I could go on for hours honestly.  It seems obvious to me that the overall US stock market must mean-revert, at least in real terms.

Meanwhile I expect commodities, which reached historic relative lows in early 2020, to eventually continue
to mean-revert the other way as they have generally been doing since late 2020.

I don’t know when it will happen.  This bubble is nothing compared to Japan in 1990.  I try to find investments that will do well regardless, and

author: BJJblue34
body: Apple currently has its highest PE ratio in its history. So, the company never traded at >50x. ComparingTesla to Apple for growing into high PEs doesn't make sense. Amazon is an exception. It has at times had a PE of >1000x. However, for every Amazon with a large PE you have a Intel or Cisco that have still not surpassed their 2000 price high. That doesn't even mention all the companies that eventually failed. My take is Tesla is a good company but current valuations don't make sense.

author: JungAndReckless6
body:
Mainly that cloud native products offer significantly more optionality than anything Cisco ever offered, considerably higher margins, and that Cisco got way ahead of itself in the dot com bubble without the secular shift to technology that we’ve seen in the last 10 years. 

Plus, management in many of these large cap tech companies are often the same type of wacky visionaries that I love to see in leadership. I don’t necessarily advocate buying something like NET or CRWD at these prices, and significant returns might take several years, but strong management and a fantastic product with a secular shift behind it is the way I like to invest. Hell, if you value most of these companies on an EV/GP basis and take into account their growth and major trends in the world I’d argue that they’re cheaper than many value stocks.

There will absolutely be rotations into and out of tech though, but I don’t try to time anything.

author: -AceStar
body:
Yeah that's understandable. The good hedges in that regard is that MAXN is originally the spin-off of SPWR's international assets. So although the US market is extremely lucrative for solar, MAXN has a lot of different revenue streams outside of the US. For instance they own 20% of a very large Joint Venture with a chinese semiconductor company, and as of now most of their revenue comes from outside of the states.

Second point is that the hype (or lack thereof) won't matter much if they sustain growth and turn cash flow positive. A good example of this is Enphase, still within solar admittedly with a different core business: once they turned positive in EBITDA the valuation has absolutely soared (feel free to take a look at ENPH stock for the last few yrs).

MAXN has over a billion in tangible assets and fairly limited debt, in my opinion it is a hidden gem at these valuations.

author: lostinspace509
body:
To add to what SeaCuCu is saying.  Basically that video is talking about accounting value, NOT stock market value (Market Cap).  Since you seem to be trying to program something in an algorithm to estimate the future I would say you need to look into analysts recommendations, for the purpose of estimating the future they are the ones that big business use, big fish use.  In general if a stock (Revenues or Profits) are growing faster than the market, a higher P/E will follow, as people assume that growth will continue for longer.

Discounted Cash flow will work also but you always have an issue with the Pt+1 (again, this is where Analysts Recommendations will play a role).  An interesting stock to study and you will only need to study its trajectory for two year is ENPH.  Good luck!

author: soi_boiiiiiiiiiiii
body:
People here are saying invest in funds but I disagree. The reason I say that is because you're likely younger, have a smaller cash pot and can tolerate more risk than somebody who has their whole life savings in stocks.

If you want slow long term growth then fine, go for index funds, but with your cash stack I would invest in mid-high cap growth stocks like apple, dis, se, sq.

All of your stocks are just subject to a ridiculous amount of volatility and will only ever perform well in a strong bull market. The moment the market starts to bear, you will lose all of your gains and be back at square 1.

my current portfolio ($20k) by order of size

VTI / SE / MSFT / AAPL / DIS / BRK.B / NVDA / COST / HD / SQ / ENPH

author: Haudenosaunee23
body:
I was wondering if anyone here has had any experience in the solar industry. Me being from the outside looking in, the business model of installing solar panels in individual homes seems inefficient. Why don't companies and state governments  prefer a central solar farm and having consumers get tax credits from buying energy from solar companies? When coal or petrol generators came out no one thought to put them in every single suburban home. I understand that people can save on bills and increase housing valuations but is that enough to try to generate power on your own?

I like to think that renewable energy will be part of the future but I am hesitant to invest in a solar ETF like TAN if most businesses are organized in an unfamiliar way. Maybe I am missing an important factor in this. Stocks like ENPH just seem so overvalued to me.
